importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when James Comey launched his legal efforts to have federal charges thrown out, marking a pivotal moment in the public discourse around executive overreach and judicial accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the federal charges against James Comey were initiated by the Trump Justice Department, and the subsequent legal response began in late September 2025.

keyTakeAways: James Comey is facing criminal charges for allegedly lying during congressional testimony, specifically for providing false statements and obstructing a congressional proceeding.
Comey’s defense claims the prosecution is a personal vendetta by President Donald Trump, citing a pattern of public attacks on Comey by Trump.

Comey’s legal team argues that Trump’s appointment of Lindsey Halligan as interim US attorney was unlawful, as it bypassed the Senate confirmation process after the 120-day limit for interim appointments had expired.
Comey’s attorneys claim that the Justice Department failed to charge other top Trump administration officials, suggesting selective and vindictive prosecution.

Comey’s defense highlights that Trump’s prior indictment in Florida — dismissed due to unlawful appointment of Jack Smith — supports the argument that Trump’s appointment of Halligan was also unconstitutional.
The case raises constitutional concerns about executive overreach, especially regarding the use of prosecutorial power as a tool of retaliation for political criticism.
Legal experts suggest that judges may be more receptive to such claims given the public record of Trump’s attacks on individuals being investigated.

summaryOfNewsArticle: James Comey, the former FBI director, has launched a legal defense against federal charges of lying and obstructing a congressional proceeding, arguing that the prosecution is a politically motivated personal vendetta by President Donald Trump and that the appointment of interim US Attorney Lindsey Halligan was unlawful due to bypassing Senate confirmation after the 120-day interim limit. Comey’s attorneys claim that Trump has publicly attacked him in retaliation for his criticism of the administration, and they point to the dismissal of Trump’s own indictment in Florida — over similar constitutional grounds — as precedent. They also request access to the Justice Department’s prosecutorial decisions to show selective prosecution. The case raises significant constitutional and political questions about executive power, retaliation, and the integrity of the justice system.
title: James Comey launches major efforts to have case thrown out
